channel.title: [PI] pumpkins
channel.description: So I made a halloween event, and the npc's dropped pumpkins. I decided today I wanted to edit it so you can basically smash the pumpkin(no need for animation), and it would turn into a halloween mask. But I don't really know the first place to start. I want to make it so there's an option to "smash" pumpkin along with "use" and "drop" Could someone help me?

item.title: [PI] pumpkins
item.dc:creator: @relexlawl relexlawl
item.description:
@relexlawl wrote:

[quote=“imsuperman05, post:27, topic:465664”][quote author=relexlawl link=topic=571524.msg4138515#msg4138515 date=1351917282]

[quote author=imsuperman05 link=topic=571524.msg4138403#msg4138403 date=1351909125]

[quote author=relexlawl link=topic=571524.msg4138262#msg4138262 date=1351896005]

[quote author=imsuperman05 link=topic=571524.msg4138009#msg4138009 date=1351876850]

enums are used with static data. Those values aren’t going to change at all during runtime so you should be using an enum rather than an int array.

What are you going on about? Have you heard of the declaration “final”?..

Why would you even think about storing something like this in an enum…
[/quote]negative and negative cancels each other out

int[] array should mainly be used, not as final or static, but for values that would change throughout the program and remain one instance

enum should mainly be used for values that will be final and, of course, static.

Negative and negative = positive. Not null.

“int[] array should mainly be used, not as final or static, but for values that would change throughout the program and remain one instance” - What the fuck are you talking about? XDD

Arrays and enums are the same, so it’s a PERSONAL PREFERENCE, since an enum’s .values() method iterates through the objects as it would in a loop with an array, BUT with common sense you would not use an enum when defining 3 objects and them only having 1 value (int in this case), enum has a lot of great features and I’m all for using enums, but only when you would actually take advantage of the features.
[/quote]they’re definitely not the same, i don’t know how you could make that inference

Are you capable of comprehending text? If so you should read it and use your knowledge that was taught to you during pre-school and narrow the idea down…I obviously meant in this case it would be used for the same purpose, which is to get the item id… Which is why I mentioned that the enum’s values method just iterates through the objects like an array…Now if you’re going to reply to this, at least attempt to use a valid argument.
[/quote]yeeeeaaaah i’mma just say that i don’t care. i just wanted to see how far you would go on such a small useless matter.

Then people wonder why r-s says moparscape’s community is immature.
[/quote]Immaturity is raging at anybody that tells you about another solution to the problem, and not your way.[/quote]

http://dictionary.reference.com/browse/immature

Read full topic

[/quote]they’re definitely not the same, i don’t know how you could make that inference

If so you should read it and use your knowledge that was taught to you during pre-school and narrow the idea down…I obviously meant in this case it would be used for the same purpose, which is to get the item id… Which is why I mentioned that the enum’s values method just iterates through the objects like an array…Now if you’re going to reply to this, at least attempt to use a valid argument.
[/quote]yeeeeaaaah i’mma just say that i don’t care. i just wanted to see how far you would go on such a small useless matter.

item.dc:creator: @relexlawl relexlawl
item.description:
@relexlawl wrote:

[quote=“imsuperman05, post:19, topic:465664”][quote author=relexlawl link=topic=571524.msg4137434#msg4137434 date=1351821304]

enums are used with static data. Those values aren’t going to change at all during runtime so you should be using an enum rather than an int array.

What are you going on about? Have you heard of the declaration “final”?..

Why would you even think about storing something like this in an enum…
[/quote]negative and negative cancels each other out

int[] array should mainly be used, not as final or static, but for values that would change throughout the program and remain one instance

enum should mainly be used for values that will be final and, of course, static.[/quote]

Negative and negative = positive. Not null.

“int[] array should mainly be used, not as final or static, but for values that would change throughout the program and remain one instance” - What the fuck are you talking about? XDD

Arrays and enums are the same, so it’s a PERSONAL PREFERENCE, since an enum’s .values() method iterates through the objects as it would in a loop with an array, BUT with common sense you would not use an enum when defining 3 objects and them only having 1 value (int in this case), enum has a lot of great features and I’m all for using enums, but only when you would actually take advantage of the features.

[/quote]

(Unless you’re saying to use an array of ints rather than an enum, in which case you have no clue what you’re doing).[/quote]

What?

item.description:

[quote=“mc wobbla, post:3, topic:465664”][quote author=Team_Rocket link=topic=571524.msg4136407#msg4136407 date=1351738778]
The additional right-click option can be added via Client.

Server sided:

UseItem packet

DeleteItem

AddItem
[/quote]

probably a stupid question, I’m tired right now lol.
I got it to use hammer on pumpkin, give a mask, how would I make it give one of the three H’ween masks randomly? :s[/quote]

Declare the Masks and use math to randomly select one.
